$OLECTRA.NSE is ZOOMIN. The stock is up a whopping 150% from its 52-week-low of Rs 384 in February 2023. Here are 3 main reasons why? 🤓

Firstly, a slew of major tender wins. It bagged the biggest-ever order of 2,100 electric buses worth Rs 3,675 cr from Mumbai’s state-run public transporter. In March, it also won a contract for 550 electric buses from the Telangana state government. And a month before that, it announced a tie-up with Reliance Industries to develop hydrogen buses. 💸

Secondly, it had a KILLER FY23. Profits rose 86% to Rs 34 cr, while revenue jumped 84% to Rs 1,090 cr. FYI - Over the last 3 years, its revenue has grown at a CAGR of 97%, while net profit has grown 188%. 📊

Olectra is also in an expansion phase. In Q4 FY23, Olectra entered the electric tipper biz. It also acquired 150 acres of land in Telangana to set up a new greenfield plant. This will allow it to produce 5,000 vehicles per year, which can be scaled up to 10,000 over the next few years. 🚌 Bullish

$TATACOMM.NSE is on a red, hot streak! The stock has nearly 2x over the past year.

So, what’s popping? Well, in 2019, the Tata Group was considering SELLING the company’s assets because it was bleeding money. Since then, it’s come a long way. The firm has recorded 11 successive quarters of net profit. EBITDA margins are up from 14%-15% to 24%-25%. Return on capital employed was 8.3% in 2019; now at 28%. 📊

A large part of this turnaround is due to how it shifted its operating model. This includes moving into higher-margin products like cyber security + IoT solutions and shifting customer-facing jobs to India to take advantage of a lower cost base.👨‍💻

Moving up the value chain is good. The company hopes that digital services revenue will grow 35% from FY24-FY27. But a lot depends on whether it can convince customers it isn’t just an old-fashioned service provider for telecom companies. PS – after the recent rally, analysts see limited scope of upside from current levels! 🤙 Bullish

$NYKAA.NSE Investor Day 2023: Top Takeaways

Shifting sands: The company has diversified heavily. The beauty & personal care (BPC) segment made up 98% of its GMV (gross merchandise value) in FY20, which dropped to 68% in FY23. A large part of the new biz comes from its fashion vertical. Its current ‘total addressable market’ is now ~$100 billion, which will grow to $180 billion by 2027. 👖

In-house brands: Nykaa is trying to grow its private labels. Its women innerwear brand hit Rs 85 cr in sales within 2 years. Kay, its beauty brand, hit Rs 128 cr in sales in FY23 and currently has a reach of 300 stores. 🛍️

Physical stores: The company believes in a decent mix of online + offline retail. It plans to open 50 new stores in FY24. FYI – its physical stores turn EBITDA positive usually within 1 year of launch. 📍

$MEDANTA.NSE $PPLPHARMA.NSE $WIPRO.NSE $PNB.NSE $VBL.NSE 

Global Index provider FTSE announced changes to its India indices. Medanta or Global Health and Piramal Pharma will see inflows of $8.1 million and $11.1 million respectively. Besides this, Wipro, Punjab National Bank and Varun Beverages saw an increase in weightage. Why’s this important? Global passive funds closely follow FTSE indices and replicate their portfolios based on the stock weights within those indices. When the stock weights in the index change, these funds adjust their holdings by buying or selling the corresponding stocks. Bullish

$TRENT.NSE has been KILLING IT. The stock hit an all-time high of Rs 1,687 p/sh after rallying  +26% this year vs just a +4% gain for the Nifty 500 index.

What’s going on? For starters, the company POPPED OFF in FY23: revenue nearly 2x to Rs, 7715 cr, while net profit was up +10x at Rs 394 cr. The post-Covid “revenge shopping” tailwind has shown no signs of slowing down. Consequently, to meet this increased demand, Trent has been on an aggressive store expansion drive. 

In FY23, the company opened a total of 119 new stores (Westlife + Zudio), a +30% YoY increase. Besides this, Trent is also scaling up its product offerings. PS - emerging categories like beauty & personal care, innerwear and footwear made up nearly a fifth of its standalone revenues. 

Brokerages are bullish on the company’s long-term business outlook. But warn that high valuations may restrict significant upside. PS - ICICI Sec has a target of Rs 1,730 p/sh; +2% from current levels. Bullish

$NIFTYBANK.NSE $NIFTYIT.NSE

Should you have bet on bank stocks and dumped IT firms? A new report by Jefferies says you shouldn’t have to leave it to guesswork. 

Their analysis of the two indices over the last 14 years indicates that they generally perform in the OPPOSITE directions. Why? There are many factors, but historically, banks tend to outperform during times of good macro conditions. IT companies do well during weaker macro conditions

How much longer should we expect this bank-IT cycle to continue? Jefferies says there’s still some ways to go. 

For banks, asset quality is looking good + fast transmission of rate hikes has widened margins. FYI - rating agency ICRA estimates FY24 credit growth to be the 2nd-highest ever. Finally, even though bank stocks have hit ATHs, valuations still look fairly reasonable! 

For IT, a slowing global economy has taken its toll. Outlooks are weak as well and despite this, valuations for most companies are still above historical averages!

$IEX.NSE CRASHED nearly 15% intraday to hit a new 2-year low.

Ssup bro? Reports indicate that the GOI may speed up the process of ‘market coupling’ in the power sector. As part of this, an independent entity will likely take charge of price discovery for spot power trading. Basically, a super exchange (mostly owned by GOI) will aggregate bids & offers across power exchanges to arrive at a uniform mkt clearing price.

What does this mean? This SUCKS for IEX as it would increase competition and reduce their competitive edge. Currently, IEX enjoys an almost 100% market share in Day-Ahead Market (DAM) and Real-Time-Market (RTM) segments, which contributes to 75%-80% of its volumes. Experts believe that rivals will now start to chip away at its dominance. 

Bottomline: IEX shot into the spotlight during the 2021 bull run, hitting an all-time high of Rs 295 p/sh. The stock has more than halved since. FYI - brokerage firm Antique Broking sees an ADDITIONAL -15% downside from current levels. Bearish

$AETHER.NSE 

Aether Industries is one of the few specialty chemical companies in India with three separate business models – large-scale manufacturing, contract manufacturing, and contract research and manufacturing services (CRAMS). The company’s R&D-focused approach has allowed it to  develop new products, serve high-end product markets and capture market share from China. 📊

The chemical manufacturer’s strong R&D capability has become its moat. Some of Aether’s products are the first to be made in India. Domestic firms are substituting exports for Aether’s products. Demand from overseas is also growing. In March 2023, Japan’s Otsuka Chemical signed a 10-year supply deal with the company. 🌎

In terms of the risks, investors need to watch out for rising raw material costs, a slowdown in the pharma and agrochemical industries, and Aether’s expensive market valuations (PE of 88). 👀

PS - JM Financial sees a +16% from current levels. Keep an eye on this one. ✅ Bullish

$WESTLIFE.NSE Westlife Foodworld has been KILLING it. The stock is up 59% over the last year. It has easily beaten quick service restaurant (QSR) peers like Jubilant Foodworks (-2%),  Devyani International (+16%), Restaurant Brands Asia (17%) or Sapphire Foods India (+28%). What’s popping? 🔥

Simply put, business is red hot. In FY23, net sales hit an all-time high of Rs 2,270 cr, a 36% growth in  ‘same-store sales growth’. Consequently, the company reported a first net profit (Rs 112 cr) in 4 years!!! Westlife also managed to weather the high inflation storm far better than peers like Jubilant Foodworks. Fun Fact: Westlife has 2x longer leases per store compared to the industry average. This helps keeps costs down, boosting operating margins. With the Covid disruption over, it plans to open 300 new stores by FY27. 📈

What is the FAME policy?

The Fame India scheme or "Faster Adoption and Manufacturing of Electric and Hybrid Vehicles in India" is an incentive programme that promotes the use of electric and hybrid automobiles. 🚗
(2/8)

Electric car manufacturers and infrastructure providers receive this incentive in the form of subsidies with a budget of 10,000 crore. 💸

(3/8)

The government announced the Fame India Scheme in two phases 👀

* Phase I: was started in 2015 and was functional till 31st March 2019.

* Phase II: was started in April 2019 and was active till 31st March 2022 and now extended till March 31, 2024.

$ZOMATO.NSE Zomato ended FY23 on a delicious note! The last 12 months were NOT the perfect bite, but the company set its kitchen in order. Is it enough to set up a successful FY24? Let’s take a look. 🔍

A quick Q4 lowdown: Strong growth in food delivery + B2B verticals helped the top line jump (57% YoY). Losses narrowed (-48% YoY) to Rs 188 cr. Average monthly transacting customers hit a record high of 16.6 million. 💪

But the real story is that for 3 out of the last 4 quarters, the company’s food delivery biz was EBITDA POSITIVE. Thirteen years after it started, Zomato’s core cash cow is no longer burning money. 💰

Going forward, CEO Deepinder Goyal said that the next big goal was to hit profitability at an overall level in the next year. What are the hurdles that can get his way? 🤔

$SBIN.NSE $ICICIBANK.NSE $HDFC.NSE $TITAN.NSE $LODHA.NSE 

The great exchange of Rs 2,000 notes is now underway! No, it isn’t Demonetisation 2.0 (the banknotes will remain legal tender even after the deadline). Here’s a list of sectors/stocks that will gain for this move.

1) Banks & NBFCs: If ALL the Rs 2,000 banknotes come back into the system, lenders will see a 2% growth in deposits. Higher deposits in general are a POSITIVE for their net interest margins. Morgan Stanley estimates the liquidity impact to be between Rs 1.4 lakh crore to Rs 1.6 lakh cr! FYI – PSU banks are expected to gain more, according to experts. ✅

2) Real estate & gold companies: Going to the bank can be a tedious exercise. Yes, even for people who can explain why they have large amounts of Rs 2,000 notes lying around. One quick way to spend that money is on high-value purchases like jewelry and land/flats. Experts believe consumer spending will be up in these sectors over the next couple of months. 📈

The US needs a solution as soon as possible because if the debt ceiling is not increased, it will default on its debts, a historic first with serious implications.

As negotiations enter a crisis phase, here is a primer of the #debt ceiling and its implications.

A 🧵

2/ What is the #USDebt ceiling?

* The debt ceiling sets a cap on how much money the US government may borrow.
* To fund programmes like social security, Medicare, and the armed forces.
* Excess of government expenditure over revenue leads to deficits.

3/ This deficit gets added to the country's total debt at the end of the year.

As a result, the #USTreasury issued government securities to raise funds that would be repaid with interest.

Upon reaching its debt limit, the Treasury cannot issue any further securities.

$HAL.NSE has been ZOOMIN. The defence stock is up nearly 2x over the last year, easily beating the Nifty 50 Index.

1/ Price wars from ONDC pose a threat to the duopoly of Zomato and Swiggy. Here’s how?

A thread 🧵

2/ So what is ONDC?  

-ONDC was launched in late 2021 under the Department for Promotion of Industry and Internal Trade (DPIIT).
-It allows consumer-facing firms to use e-commerce platforms' listing, order mgmt, and delivery technologies.

3/ How does it work?

-ONDC is charging restaurants a commission of 8-10%,
-While Swiggy and Zomato charge 18–25% as commission.
-The cost savings in direct commission are made available to customers directly.

4/ These brands’ products are 30–80% cheaper on Paytm, Magicpin, and PhonePe than Swiggy and Zomato.

-McDonald's
-Taco Bell
-Behrouz Biryani
-Wow Momo
-Pizza Hut
-Cafe Coffee Day products

5/ The big picture:

-Early discounts and
-A cheaper food delivery system
-Has helped the government-backed ONDC exceed 10,000 daily orders.

$ZOMATO.NSE dropped over -6% today. 📉

WTF is ONDC? It’s a GOI-backed open-source platform that connects sellers, buyers and logistics firms in one place. It has apps that serve as the online storefront (Paytm, Magicpin) merchants that sell their products, and delivery firms (Dunzo, Shadowfax etc) which fulfill the order. 🚐

For most items, ONDC is cheaper than rivals Zomato or Swiggy by 20%-30%. In New Delhi, the price of a ‘Big Paneer Burger’ from McDonald’s is currently Rs 359 on Zomato. Its cost on ONDC? Just Rs 270. 💸

On paper, this works out CHEAPER. This is because ONDC’s partners (Paytm or Dunzo) charge a commission of only 2%-6%. In comparison, Swiggy and Zomato take 18%-25% from restaurants to pay for their massive and centralized overhead. 💰

The fine print? ONDC currently has a pretty big ‘incentive’ program – aka subsidies and discounts. When the dust settles, it will be clear if Swiggy and Zomato are just expensive middlemen Bearish

$INDIGO.NSE hit a fresh 52-week-high of Rs 2,236.95 p/sh. The stock is set to gain BIG TIME from rival Go First’s bankruptcy.

The case for a future rally is simple: In the March 2023 quarter, Go First had a market share of 7.8% and carried 29 lakh passengers. Its insolvency will remove 9% of domestic supply in the aviation sector. All players will benefit, but Go First’s low-cost carrier brand means its customers are likely headed to IndiGo. 

Credit Suisse believes that leasing companies might allocate some of Go First’s aircraft to Indigo as they share similar fleet types. FYI - this is what happened with Spice Jet when Jet Airways collapsed.

Beyond this, there are other positive triggers:

1) Travel demand is BOOMING. India’s domestic air traffic hit a record high on April 30. Also, 38 million passengers flew in just the first three months of 2023, a 52% YoY bump.

2) Price of aviation turbine fuel has dropped over the last 3 months due to a softening in global oil prices. Bullish

$CENTRALBK.NSE $BANKBARODA.NSE $BBTC.NSE $BOMDYEING.NSE 

Low-cost carrier, Go First --owned by the Wadia Group-- declared BANKRUPTCY.

GoFirst says it went bust because half its fleet was grounded over faulty engines supplied by Pratt & Whitney. The airline argues that P&W refused to supply it with spare engines, in violation of an arbitration order. 

But, there were other issues too. GoFirst began to seriously struggle post-Covid. In FY22, Go First recorded its biggest-ever loss of Rs 1,808 cr. The airline’s market share nearly halved to 6.9% in March 2023. 

So, who are the other major losers in this debacle?

The banks. Go First owes over Rs 5,500 cr to a clutch of lenders. Its insolvency filing says Central Bank of India (-5%) has the highest exposure of Rs 1,561 cr. Bank of Baroda (Rs 1,423 cr) and Deutsche Bank (Rs 1,320 cr) are the other big lenders.   

Other Wadia group firms. In particular, Bombay Burmah Trading Co and Bombay Dyeing fell 5%-6% each.

Shares of Gujarat-based PSU companies were up BIG TIME. Why, you ask? The rally is due to a state government order that mandates a MINIMUM level of dividends and bonus shares to shareholders. 🚀

Here are the deets for those who care: All listed state PSUs will be required to pay a minimum dividend that is at least 30% of their profits or 5% of their net worth, whichever is higher. For bonus shares, all companies whose reserves and surplus are 10x their paid-up equity share capital are required to issue them. 🤑

While most Gujarat PSUs have done well financially, their dividend track record has been poor. Also, most of these firms don’t require immediate capex, which means they’re sitting on idle cash. That’s why this move is a welcome surprise. 👌 Bullish

1/ El Niño and its impact on India's economy.

A thread 🧵

2/ What is El Niño? 

El Niño is an abnormal warming of the surface waters in the eastern tropical Pacific Ocean. This occurs every four to 12 years and affects rainfall patterns around the world. 

3/ During El Niño, monsoon in India is often weaker, leading to a dip in agricultural production. Nearly 70% of India's farms depend on rainfall, which makes up 18% of India's GDP.

4/ It is estimated that 60% of all droughts in India in the last 130 years have coincided with an El Niño. These have been years when rainfall was over 10% less than normal.

5/ Private weather forecaster Skymet expects India to receive “below normal” monsoon rains in 2023! 👀 

Punjab, Haryana, Rajasthan and Uttar Pradesh, the agricultural bowl of north India, are likely to observe less-than-normal rains during the second half of the season.

$PAYTM.NSE Starting April 1, users of digital wallets like Paytm Wallet or PhonePe Wallet can transact on the UPI network! 🥳

1/ Starting Jan 27, all large-cap blue chip stocks will move to a T+1 settlement system. This is a BIGGG deal!

A thread 🧵

Let’s first understand what the settlement system is? It means that the shares are now officially owned by the buyer and the seller has rec the cash payment.

2/ Indian stock exchanges currently follow a T+2 system; this means if you buy shares on Monday they will be credited to your Demat account on Wednesday. This system has been in place since April 2003! 💪

3/ The new T+1 settlement system will benefit traders in more ways than one! It’ll boost their liquidity as they get the funds a day earlier thus reducing the risk of default. Margin requirements may also go down which in turn may shoot up trading volumes, which is a positive!

2022 was a tricky year for financial markets. Developed countries are witnessing multi-decade high inflation vs low (0-2%) inflation in the past. 

The 20th century was marked by numerous geopolitical conflicts but the 21st century seemed different until Russia invaded Ukraine.

Low-interest rates (near 0%) and easy money policies over the past 10 years reversed almost instantaneously in 2022. The US FED raised interest rates by an insane 7 time last year including 4 back 2 back 75 bps rate hikes. 

While growth concerns intensify globally in 2023, India’s growth trends may remain resilient given our macroeconomic stability and well-controlled inflation.

So what does the new year hold for Indian investors? Most experts believe that stocks may have an underwhelming 2023 because of two main reasons. Firstly, they say valuations have turned expensive after our recent outperformance leaving little room for further upside.

$IDEA.NSE is in a big mess.

Here’s a quick recap: In Sept 2021, the GOI approved a relief package that allowed Vi to convert Rs 16,000 cr in outstanding interest payments to equity. This would make the Indian Government the largest shareholder in the company with a ~36% stake. 🧐

But there’s a twist. As part of the deal, Vi had assured the Govt that they would invest Rs 10,000 cr from their own pockets. But, they’ve failed to do so. Consequently, the GOI has decided to delay the equity conversion of its debt, which is a huge NEGATIVE! 👎

Vi desperately needs funds to continue its operations. To fix this, they went to SBI and a bunch of other banks to borrow money. But, the banks refused to give them a loan as there is no clarity on GOI’s stake and fund infusion by promoters. PS - Vi already owes more than Rs 15,000 cr to banks. 🤯

As I’ve always said, finding a sustainable and scalable business model is priority #1 for Vi. Without it, there’s only so much cash it can burn.

$RELIANCE.NSE Seems like mota bhai is getting ready to take the leadership. The past 6 months, RIL has barely moved (+1%) vs $NIFTY50.NSE gaining nearly 18%. 

The main reason for this underperformance was the shock windfall tax on fuel exports imposed by the GOI back in July. As oil prices have cooled off, refining margins have shrunk sharply. Experts are optimistic that Govt may soon withdraw the hefty duties. PS - they did so in case of steel as well. 

If that were to happen, RIL’s refining margins may move up by $2 per barrel. This translates to a $1 billion gain on the EBITDA front, which is a massive W!!! 

Besides this, telecom and retail are also killing it. Jio continues to grow faster than industry as per latest TRAI data. Reliance Retail successfully launched its FMCG business under the “Independence” brand last week. 

Watch out for this one 🔥 🔥🔥 Bullish

Equirus Research on Birla Corporation: (LONG | TP: 1239, Upside: +19%)

# BCORP has registered a 10% volume growth CAGR over FY16 – FY22 at a time vs. industry volumes growth of ~5-6%. With recent commissioning of Mukutban capacity, company has reached 19.3 mtpa installed capacity and is transitioning from being a small player to a mid-sized player in the cement space.

# Continued govt. focus on infra across India, we expect cement industry to clock 7-8% volume CAGR during the period. Believe there is enough room to also gain mkt share via capacity addition into newer geographies, product launches & increasing dealer penetration.

# With prices of Pet-coke correcting by 20-25% in last 3-4 months, we expect some recovery in margins coming from 4Q23 onwards.

# Valuation: At current valuations, stock is trading at 7.5x FY24 EV/EBITDA. We believe that stock can see further upside as volume growth/easing of cost pressure thesis plays out. Bullish

$BANDHANBNK.NSE CLSA upgrades Bandhan to BUY from O-PF. Target 300 (indicating a 28% upside from current level)

They say: 

Bandhan Bank has lagged most MFIs in this cyclical recovery due to concentrated exposure in MFI-leveraged states and high restructuring during Covid, which eventually turned bad. While we believe MFI is not underpenetrated, especially in east India, we expect Bandhan to finally benefit from the cyclical recovery in MFI collections/growth. Its non-MFI portfolio is now growing consistently and provides some diversification. We cut our estimates by 26% for FY23 and 3-5% FY24/25CL and expect provisioning to ease from 4QFY23. We expect FY24/25CL ROEs at ~20%. Multiples at 1.6x FY24 book look cheap and hence we upgrade Bandhan Bank to BUY from O-PF on normalising MFI cycle. Bullish

$TSLA key takeaways from Tesla’s analyst call 

Elon: long-term trend has been extremely good. And several years ago, I said: it was possible for Tesla to be worth more than Apple, which was then the highest market cap company, I think, in the market. And Apple at that time, I think it was around $700 billion. 

And I said it required incredible execution, at least some luck, and we did indeed achieve that. Tesla went, in fact, or passed Apple’s market cap at the time. 

And now, I have the opinion that we can far exceed Apple’s current market cap. In fact, I see a potential path for Tesla to be worth more than Apple and Saudi Aramco combined. 

So, now that doesn’t mean it will happen or that will be easy. In fact, I think it will be very difficult. It will require a lot of work, some very creative new products, manage expansion and always the luck. Bullish
